key_title: Key to the species of Persoonia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Proteaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Proteaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Proteaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves mostly less than 2 mm wide; inflorescences growing on into a leafy shoot
Leaves mostly more than 2 mm wide; inflorescences terminated by a dormant bud or growing on into a leafy shoot
Leaves mostly acute but never pungent-pointed
Leaves pungent-pointed, rigid
Pedicels and tepals usually glabrous; widespread prostrate or decumbent plant
Pedicels and tepals hairy; erect shrub of East Gippsland
Leaves less than 2.5 cm long
Longest leaves more than 2.5 cm long
Leaves mostly broadest at or below middle
Leaves broadest above middle; uncommon shrub of northern Victoria
Pedicels hairy; tepal tips acute to apiculate; Snowy Plains subalps
Pedicels usually glabrous; tepal tips shortly caudate; upper Genoa River area
Tepals less than 16 mm long, broad-linear, glabrous or hairy; shrubs to c. 6 m high
Tepals 16–20 mm long, narrowly linear, silky; tree to c. 10 m high, in forests between c. Kinglake and Powelltown
Bark fissured, loose, many-layered and papery, dark outside, inner layers dark red; East Gippsland
Bark smooth, light to mid grey, sometimes dark and fissured (but not layered and papery) at base or on lower trunk
Leaves 1–10 mm wide, more or less straight
Leaves mostly more than 12 mm wide, more or less asymmetric to falcate
Leaves linear, mostly 2–3 mm wide, 2.5–5 cm long
Leaves narrowly lanceolate, 5–10 mm wide, 5–10 cm long
Anthers white; leaves more or less flat, strongly discolorous

Anthers yellow; leaf-margins usually slightly recurved, lamina somewhat incurved longitudinally toward apex, concolorous to discolorous; uncommon shrub of dry forests and heaths in the west to north-east
Flowers several in short axillary (sometimes apparently terminal) racemes; all or most inflorescences terminated by a dormant bud
Flowers solitary in axils of leaves; shoots growing on beyond flowering region; rare, usually velvety shrub or small tree of north-eastern montane to subalpine forests
Perianth and branchlets densely pubescent; leaves mostly opposite; shrub of drier lowlands to subalps east of c. Erica
Perianth and branchlets glabrescent; leaves mostly alternate; shrub or small tree of moist to wet forests of far East Gippsland
